item.title: Being Opinionated for the Sake of Dialectics
item.description: I don't consider myself opinionated, actually quite the opposite. Often good arguments can be found for and against the same position and if you commit to one side too early, you may look pretty dumb in hindsight. Most problems worth thinking about, by their very nature, cannot be solved by armchair science alone. You need to collect evidence, make inferences, maybe come up with a simplified model that represents only some aspects of reality. There is ample opportunity for errors on each step of the way and even in the absence of errors, any new evidence has the potential to turn the tables. Claiming to know the truth feels presumptuous.

item.title: Why Blogs Make Outstanding Books
item.description: Can a blog be turned into a book? Yes! But it can't be just any old blog - the writer has to have something to say and no fear of saying it... like Troy Hunt. Here's the story of how I turned his blog into a book.

item.title: Git - Git Configuration
item.description: So far, we’ve covered the basics of how Git works and how to use it, and we’ve introduced a number of tools that Git provides to help you use it easily and efficiently. In this chapter, we’ll see how you can make Git operate in a more customized fashion, by introducing several important configuration settings and the hooks system. With these tools, it’s easy to get Git to work exactly the way you, your company, or your group needs it to.
